title: What is a Memorandum of Costs after judgement, acknowledgement of credit, and declaration of Accrued interest?
question: I just rec'd the notice in the mail. It looks like a notice to collect $$ on case judgement. I've not received any court docs, subpoena to appear in court, or notice that I am being sued by a creditor. I've heard that some of the collection agencies are using these tactics to scare people into paying on their debts. I am not familiar with the legal system but at the same time don't want any problems with the laws. I would be grateful for guidance on this.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Filing a lawsuit,Summons and complaint,Subpoena,Default judgment
answers:
What you have received, often referred to as a Cost Memorandum, can only be filed in a civil lawsuit after a judgment has been rendered. If you have no prior information that a lawsuit was commenced against you, you are probably the victim of what is sometimes referred to as "sewer service", a New York slang term referring to the unethical and illegal practice of process servers who throw the summons and complaint intended to be served on a defendant instead down the sewer grate, and then fill out a proof of service claiming the summons and complaint were personally served upon the defendant.

While you have the right to file a motion in the court where the judgment has been entered to have the default judgment set aside based upon the lack of proper service, it may not be worth the time and expense if you do not also have a defense to the claim, such as the debt is not yours or has been paid. The lack of ability to pay one's debts does not constitute a defense.

If the debt is one of many with which you are confronted, and yet you simply lack the ability to pay, you may wish to consider seeking protection under the bankruptcy laws. Feel free to contact my office if you would like to schedule a no charge initial consultation.

The document you described is something typically filed by a creditor/plaintiff after a judgment has been entered. Most collection judgments are "default" judgments in which the defendants are not aware of the case or do not defend the case.
If you feel the judgement has been entered without your knowledge and you have defenses to the creditor collecting the debt, you may be able to ask the Court to set aside the default due to not being served and not being aware of the case. This would typically require the assistance of an attorney.
If this is a situation where you knew about the creditor and the possibility they might sue you for not paying, breach of contract, etc., you are probably better off spending your resources filing bankruptcy to eliminate the debt, along with all your other qualifying debts. If you can qualify for a chapter 7, all your debt gets wiped out with no repayment plan very quickly and easily. If you'd like to discuss the matte further, I'd be happy to do so at no charge, please feel free to call my office anytime.

The document should have a court case number on it, along with the name of the court. You need to check the court file in the case because, if a judgment was entered against you, the creditor can garnish your wages, levy on your bank account, etc. without any advance notice to you. Depending upon which court entered the judgment, you may be able to obtain some information the the court's website and, possibly, purchase copies of the documents. Otherwise, visit the courthouse. Get a copy of the Complaint, the Proof of Service, the Judgment and any documents that the plaintiff submitted in support of entry of judgment. Then, you may need to consult a lawyer. Find a consumer lawyer or a debt collection defense lawyer.

Memorandum of Costs is a document filed with the clerk of the court to add allowable costs to the judgment award, previously entered. If you were not part of a lawsuit or served with a summons and complaint, it appears that this is an effort by the Plaintiff's lawyer to perfect a prior judgment against you.

If the case involves a creditor or debt collection agency as the plaintiff, I suggest you hire a debt collection DEFENSE attorney and get this judgment settled or set aside promptly. You have options now, but if you wait too long, then it is harder or impossible to set aside a default judgment. Typically, too long is over 90 days from date you learn of the case. Do not delay, at there will be time needed to get a copy of the documents from the courthouse to see what was filed. Calling the Plaintiff's law firm will not protect you and the call can be used later to show that you were aware of the lawsuit, as they keep notes of such conversations. Same with a letter to the law firm, it will be used to show you were aware of the case.
